results.title: Pavlovsk
results.brief_description: A picturesque film that looks at the beautiful Pavlovsk House. There is very little narration in this film but it is accompanied with music by 18th and 19th century composers and performances by members of the Leningrad Ballet Theatre.

results.title: Pavlova
results.creator_credit: Pierre Morin, Micheline Charest and R.A. Weinberg
results.brief_description: Fifty years after her death, Anna Pavlova is still considered one of the greatest ballerinas of the 20th century. This film is a tribute to the great ballerina and recreates those works which have made her immortal such as “The Dying Swan”, “Californian Poppy”, “The Dragonfly”, “Coppelia”, and many more. Performed by members of L’Ecole Superieure de Danse du Quebec and leading ballet dancers. Rated: G

results.title: Pavarotti in London
results.brief_description: The magnificent Luciano Pavarotti performing at his best in a Gala Concert performance at the Royal Albert Hall on 13th April 1982 in the presence of Her Majesty, Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, and featuring the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Kurt Herbert Adler. Recorded live on location.

results.title: Pavarotti in China: the Luciano Pavarotti Concert from the Exhibition Hall Theatre Beijing
results.brief_description: This is a live recording for television of Pavarotti’s concert performance in Beijing on June 24th 1986. This world renowned Italian singer once again presents a magnificent performance to an enthusiastic and appreciative audience, mixing popular Italian songs along with excerpts from some of the best known operas. Pavarotti is superbly supported by the Orchestra and Chorus of the Municipal Opera of Genoa with Dante Ghersi as choir master and Emerson Buckley as the conductor. Sung in Italian.

results.title: Pauline at the beach = Pauline a la plage
results.creator_credit: Margaret Menegoz, Eric Rohmer, Les Films Ariane and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Comedies et proverbes”.
Third in Rohmer’s series “Comedies et Proverbes” this gentle comedy of adult sexual mores, has as its motto a saying of Chretien de Troyes “Qui trop parole, il se mesfait” “A wagging tongue bites itself”. Pauline joins her cousin for a holiday by the sea and has her fifteen year old eyes opened to the duplicity, hypocrisy and plain silliness of adult sexual politics. As the eponymous heroine, Amanda Langlet gives a beautifully subdued performance. Winner of Best Director award at the Berlin Film Festival in 1983. French language with English subtitles.

results.title: Pauline a la Plage = Pauline at the Beach
results.creator_credit: Margaret Menegoz, Les Films du Losange, Les Films Ariane and Eric Rohmer
results.brief_description:
The third of Rohmer’s Comedies et Proverbes series (see summary for La Femme de l’Aviateur) is prefaced by a medieval motto ‘Who talks o’ermuch, himself doth harm.’ At the centre of what has been described as ‘an airy comedy of manners, encompassing genuine pain’ is 15 year-old Pauline. Her ideals are put to a severe test when, during a holiday at Normandy, she is caught up in an emotional triangle which attendant hypocrisies transforms into an even more fraught hexagon.

Credits: Producer, Margaret Menegoz ; director, writer, Eric Rohmer ; photography, Nestor Almendros ; editor, Cecile Decugis.
Cast: Amanda Langlet, Arielle Dombasle, Pascal Greggory.

results.title: Paulina 1880
results.creator_credit: Albina du Boisrouvray and Jean-Louis Bertucelli
results.brief_description:
Paulina is the only daughter of an upper class family in 19th century Italy. She grows up under the preying eyes of her large and domineering family and can only dream about love. Between her dreams and her religious devotion, she finds time to fall in love with a married nobleman. Sensing the untenability of the situation, Paulina considers entering a convent, but not before she has a last encounter with her lover.

Credits: Producer, Albina du Boisrouvray ; director, Jean-Louis Bertucelli ; writers, Albina du Boisrouvray, Jean-Louis Bertucelli ; photography, Andreas Winding ; music, Nicolas Nabokov.
Cast: Olga Karlatos, Maximilian Schell, Eliana de Santis, Michel Bouquet, Sami Frey.

results.title: Paul Tortelier: the cello. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Ken Cameron, Muir Mathieson, World Mirror-Realist Films and Anvil Film and Recording Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Opens with a brief recapitulation of the history of the instrument. Paul Tortelier with four cellists from the National Youth Orchestra plays the opening of Rossini’s William Tell Overture. The chamber works of Schumann and Brahms are discussed and Tortelier gives insights into how he combines skill, artistry and musicianship as he plays his own Toccata.

results.title: Paul Tortelier: the cello. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Ken Cameron, Muir Mathieson, World Mirror-Realist Films and Anvil Film and Recording Group
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Paul Tortelier, the French cellist and composer, conducts a master-class of four members of the National Youth Orchestra of Great Britain and instructs them in some of the finer points in the Dvorak Cell Concerto. Tortelier gives a history of cello playing and the film ends with an excerpt from the great Cello Concerto by Lalo.

results.title: Paul Tomkowicz: street railway switchman
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB and Roman Kroitor
results.brief_description: In winter the rail-switches on streetcar tracks in Winnipeg would jam with freezing mud and snow. Keeping them clean, whatever the weather, was the job of the switchman. In this film about a bygone era, Paul Tomkowicz, Polish-born Canadian, talks about his job and his life in Canada. Awards: Edinburgh; Oberhausen
